dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I'm Erica Bain, and as you know, I walk the city. I bitch and moan about it. I walk and watch and listen. I witness all the beauty and ugliness that is disappearing from our beloved city. Last week took me to the grey depths of the East River where Dimitri Panchenko swims his laps like he has since the 1960s. And today I walked by the acres of scaffolding outside what used to be the Plaza Hotel and I thought about Eloise. Remember Kay Thompson's Eloise? Eloise who lived in the Plaza Hotel, with her dog Weenie and her parents who were always away and her English nanny who had 8 hairpins made out of bones -- As she talks, we see her -- thin, semi-transperant, ghostlike. Almost nothing but voice.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: That Eloise. The adored brat of my childhood. A little punk kid pirouetting round the grand ballroom, pouring pitchers of water down the mail chute, Upper East Side anarchist in pigtails, not unlike other brats and punks this city has brought to life. Sid Vicious spewing beer from his teeth in the Chelsea Hotel. Andy Warhol, his sunglasses reflecting Valerie Solana's gun. Edgar Allen Poe freeing live monkeys from the crates of a crumbling schooner on oily slips of South Street. Stories of a city that is disappearing before our eyes, its people swept over the Williamsburg, the Holland Tunnel, the Major Degan. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: (off the storefronts) These are cool.

dialogues.text: They are really good. They're evocative, but quiet. They don't make a lot of noise. I like them.

dialogues.text: I wish. Erica, dragging a bit, sets her full drink down, heads for the door. Nicole stops her.

dialogues.text: Are you leaving?

dialogues.text: You're a shitty liar.

dialogues.text: Sorree... see you...

dialogues.text: That meant a lot to her, you know.

dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.text: (laughingly) I hate her. He puts his arm through hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come to their building. Erica sits on the stoop.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Sit here a while. It's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I got to walk him --

dialogues.text: Get my jacket, then -- He goes into the building. She sits, as UDO JOSAI, 60, Sudanese woman, a tenant in the building, walks up to the building, carrying some groceries. Erica moves over to let her by.

dialogues.speaker: JOSAI
dialogues.text: I can open my own door -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Thank you. David comes back out the door with their dog, Curtis, passing the woman on their way.

dialogues.text: I am old. But way meaner. (then) She gave me an apple. Erica takes a bite, as David puts his arm around her. Just before they leave, Erica wedges a folded newspaper in the door, props it open so they don't have to take their keys. EXT. dialogues.text: I meant it, you know. What's wrong with City Hall, tonight?

dialogues.text: Two police detectives, PITNEY and O'CONNOR, stand by Erica's bed. They are showing photographs of faces that could possibly be the killers. She shakes her head as each one comes up.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA

dialogues.text: You gotta help us here. We need something from you, anything -- As the pictures flash by.

dialogues.text: Why don't we go through it again. After he slammed your boyfriend with the pipe -- She clams up. This seems hopeless.

dialogues.text: Do you? She looks round at their faces. Men, hard and practical.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I know. You're the good guys. So why doesn't it feel like that?

dialogues.text: Erica, dressed in street clothing, sits across from a THERAPIST. There is an orderly with a wheelchair in the room. The Therapist hands her a sample pack of anti- depressants, writes her a prescription.

dialogues.text: But her head falls onto hard earth now. Lee, above, is beating the shit out of her.

dialogues.text: Erica, lying on the bed fully clothed. Trying to sleep. She can't.

dialogues.text: Erica, walking down the stairs towards the corridor that leads to the open door -- and the street outside. The corridor is long, dark, and eerie. She makes it to the half-open door, and sees the silhouetted figures of construction workers on the scaffolding opposite her building. A LOUD CRASH -- which startles her. A plank has fallen to the ground below the scaffolding. A wind blows the dark netting, covering the scaffolding. Eerie, unsettling.

dialogues.speaker: ACTION
dialogues.text: She makes it down the steps and heads down the street. Then sees -- the dark phalanx of the rock of the park, the trees above it. The same wind blowing the leaves. She can't go on, turns back. And gasps as she walks straight into the path of someone coming from behind.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Hey --

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Sorry -- She does a bad job of hiding her panic, her surprise. She heads back up the stoop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica, lying in bed, can't sleep. She takes another pill, chasing it with water. She gets up, walks around, hoping the pills will take effect but knowing they won't, just as the ones from the night before didn't. And the night before that. She goes into the --

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: Runs a BATH, puts her HAND under the water, checks the temperature... There is a HAND on her face, it is David's, trying to calm her. They are in a fight, she PUSHES HIM, his face crumbles, she hates herself. As Erica throws her arms around David, kissing him -- she is SMASHED in the face, again and again and again and again until she falls, lands almost softly on the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO ERICA, (PRESENT)
dialogues.text: Now in the bath, not flinching from the memories, taking the full force of the blows, again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TELEPHONE RINGING. Erica standing by the window, smoking. Down below, she sees JOSAI, her neighbor, cultivating the small vegetable plot in the common garden. A voice on the answer machine again. Nicole.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (on answer-machine) Hi. Me again. The pest. You didn't call. I'm coming round... Erica looks at the phone, looks at her apartment, her jail -- her jacket on the chair where it's been for days -- fuck it, it's time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica, coming down the stairs. She sees the corridor ahead of her. Walks down it. Opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sees the brightly-lit street. The figures of the construction workers, eerie under the dark netting. She makes it down the stoop. To her left is the park. To her right, the street leads to some distant projects. She chooses the right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the same street she walked at the beginning, before the attack, a street she's walked a thousand times before. Hands in the pockets of her jacket, Erica heads down the familiar, quiet three-block stretch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She MOVES FORWARD DOWN the sun-lit street, familiar with its corners, its rhythms, its shadows -- But the sunlight only increases her unease. Every shadow holds a terror for her. A youth, sitting in the shadows on the stoop, talking into his cell phone. A car up ahead, a lone man sitting in it, again on the shadowed side. She speeds up to pass the car, but the CAMERA SLOWS ON his face, the windscreen cut in half by the shadow, his face against the shadowed seat. He seems to be glaring at her. Erica's eyes start scanning the street as she walks past the MAN in the car. The CAMERA SLOWS even more -- the few feet of shadowed pavement seem to take forever to cover. She makes it past, then the car door opens behind her. The loud sound of a DOOR SLAMMING. Then FOOTSTEPS, following. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: B37
dialogues.text: THE BRAVE ONE - Rev. 8/4/06 24.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She tries to calm herself but her battered body will not listen -- her CHEST starts pounding, she wipes her sweaty hands on her coat -- the sound of his FOOTSTEPS GROW LOUDER, she can't bring herself to look around. She YANKS herself back even as she picks up her pace -- the SOUND of her QUICKENING FOOTSTEPS, his FOOTSTEPS quickening too, her breathing, her racing pulse blend together until the SOUND DROPS OUT -- and Erica's BREATHING becomes the unsettling soundtrack to her panic. The man is alongside her now, on the street side. FUCK!!!! She stops, dead. And the GUY, totally unaware of her, walks on to the newspaper stand, buys his paper, a pack of gum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica enters through the main doors. Holds onto the door handle. She looks at the lobby area of the police station -- cops moving back and forwards with guns in holsters, people milling around, sunlight streaming through the huge windows. It seems all she can to enter this public space. But she does. Walks forward to the desk.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Can I help you? She checks a card.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Detective Pitney or O'Connor please.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: They're out presently. Could anyone else help?

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I want to check on my case. I've been calling, but getting nothing but phone-tag. I thought if I came in person it might -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: What kind of case? We can see how difficult this is for her, but she manages it.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: My boyfriend was beaten to death.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Location?

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Central Park.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Name? The questions routine -- the answers unbearable.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: David Kirmani. It might be under Erica Bain.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: How long ago?

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: June eleventh. The cop hits a couple more KEYS.

dialogues.speaker: COMPUTER SCREEN
dialogues.text: FILLED WITH NAMES OF VICTIMS, LOCATIONS of ATTACKS, TIMES OF DEATH -- as he SEARCHES -- PAGE after PAGE after PAGE of CASES FILL the SCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: As she watches the COP SEARCH through computer files for her sleepless nights and battered body and dead dreams.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: A liaison officer will be down shortly to help. I know how difficult this can be. If you could please be a little patient and take a seat over there -- He points to a row of folding chairs. A couple of other PEOPLE are there waiting. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As Erica goes to the chairs, sits down, she watches the next person in line come up, give their information. The COP checks the computer. Hits a few keys.

dialogues.speaker: COP, (0O.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay, a liaison officer will be down shortly to help. I know how difficult this can be. If you could please be a little patient and take a seat over there -- He gestures to the chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's the isolation in their faces, the unbearable knowledge that what happened to them will never matter to anyone as much as it does to them -- but all of a sudden Erica gets, as we do, what they have in common -- they're victims -- and she is one of them. After a beat, she gets up and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicole comes up the sidewalk, carrying a bag of groceries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica is standing in the kitchen, watching Nicole put the groceries away.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I've been calling you. (then) You haven't picked up your phone.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I know, Nicole.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Erica -- Nicole looks at Erica -- through her eyes, eyes that haven't seen her every day, we see the change. She's thinner, hair a little longer, her eyes are distant, her hands dry, her skin clear but pale. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: A39
dialogues.text: 39 THE BRAVE ONE - Rev. 8/29/06 27.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Nicole looks around, no food, no dirty glasses or cups, no magazines, newspapers, no grocery bags, nothing, a total absence of living.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: How long has it been since you've been out? A week, ten days --

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I made it out today.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (That's good) Erica, no one expects you to go back to work, to function, but you have to --

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: What do I have to do? (Nicole)

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (pause) I know I don't know what it feels like -- and I'm so sorry this happened to you. (then) Listen, I didn't come over to bring you groceries. I came to take you someplace. Erica immediately pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Oh no. No, no.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I saw this place and I can't vouch for it -- but David would have wanted you to try --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicole and Erica enter and come upon...

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A tough GUY runs toward a WOMAN. The INSTRUCTOR shouts directions. A group of women around them on the mat.

dialogues.speaker: INSTRUCTOR
dialogues.text: Walk forward, Dana. Yell when he grabs you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 39 40 41 THE BRAVE ONE - Rev. 8/29/06 28.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She SHOUTS, thrusts her arms between his, breaks his grip. Then she knees him in the balls. Shouting "No!" after each attack. Erica, Nicole watch.

dialogues.speaker: INSTRUCTOR
dialogues.text: That's right. Find a target. Keep fighting. Hit him hard. Finish up. She blows her whistle.

dialogues.speaker: INSTRUCTOR
dialogues.text: Beautiful. Look around you. Come to the top of his head. Assess him. All together: 911. The entire class shouts "911" and cheers. Erica can not fucking stand it. She tugs at Nicole.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: We have to go, come on.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I know. Sorry. Sorry. They leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, nondescript gun store, with an outsized gun dangling above the entrance. The same gun store Erica saw in the photography show. Erica crosses the street, walks into the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young MAN, buying bullets, at the counter. Erica enters behind him, looking at the counter. A long row of shiny guns under glass. She checks them out. After the Man pays, the STORE OWNER addresses her.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Um... yeah. I want (need) to buy a gun. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: * te HOF te HOF  41 42

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He puts a He shoves She looks The Store The Store way out, ONE - Rev. 8/29/06 stack of forms on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: License?

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Oh... Of course. I needa license. forms towards her.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: When you get that -- fill these forms out -- we'll notify you in thirty days. at the forms, the guns --

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I need to buy something now.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: Sorry. That's illegal. Owner turns away.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: (desperate) Hey -- (as the guy turns back) I... I won't survive thirty days. Owner doesnt care. But the young Man, has heard the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Erica doorway, She shake 29. 41 on his 42 exits the store, the young Man is at an adjacent waiting for her.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: What happened to you? s her head, just looks at him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I don't feel safe anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (pause) Thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: (nods) I need to learn how to use it too. He looks at her, no shit.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: No shit. Follow me -- He turns the corner, into the next street, then enters a crowded fish market. Erica hesitates, outside, but notices the crowd in there, decides it's safe --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man and Erica walk down a crowded street of Asian shoppers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chinese housewives, buying all manner of fish. Erica follows the Man through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica waiting there. The young Man comes up a stairwell, with a plastic bag.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: It's a Kahr K-9. Check to see if it's loaded.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Chamber it. Pull the slide back. She does that.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: It's got an internal safety. So you dont shoot yourself. Pay me now, it's yours. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She seems to hesitate. He holds up the plastic bag.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I'll throw in the bullets. He takes out a bullet stock.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Load from the handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica lies in bed, TV ON. She picks up a bottle of anti- depressants, looks at it, sets it down. She picks up the GUN -- the weight of it, the steel, the finality -- does what the anti-depressants and sleeping pills and alcohol have failed to do, it calms her, soothes her -- She places it beneath her pillow and closes her eyes. And finally, sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MONTAGE OF SOUNDS -- as Erica walks about the city, her digital sound recorder in her shoulder bag. The mayhem of Times Square morphs into a subterranean SCREECH, as Erica holds her microphone to the grating. An overhead TRAIN ECHOES 'round an underpass, Erica beneath, recording. The CRACK of HANDBALLS in a handball alley, Erica outside the fence...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica is sitting on the stoop, and the sounds all blur into one as she fast plays through them. She is smoking. Josai walks up, heads up the stairs. Erica moves over to let her walk by. But instead, Josai sits next to her. Erica takes a drag, then offers one to Josai. Josai gives her a look. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOSAI
dialogues.text: You shouldn't smoke, it'll kill you.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I don't care. Josai looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: JOSAI
dialogues.text: There's plenty of ways to die. Josai waits for a response from Erica, and when there is none, rises --

dialogues.speaker: JOSAI
dialogues.text: But you have to figure out a way to live. Now that's hard. Josai goes inside. Erica sits there, smoking. She watches -- A stray dog walks down the street, staying in the shadows. It could have been Curtis. But it's not.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT A47
dialogues.text: Erica walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica is in the back aisle of a small market getting bottled water from the refrigerator. She's the only customer in the store. A YOUNG ASIAN WOMAN sits on a stool behind the cash register. A MAN, 30s, (SANDY) wearing a green flight jacket walks in. He looks around the store for a couple seconds. He doesn't see Erica who is obscured by the aisles. THE WOMAN (IDA) responds immediately.

dialogues.speaker: ASIAN WOMAN
dialogues.text: When did you get out --

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: So you won't let me see my kids? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There are pictures of two children, taped to the wall behind her.

dialogues.speaker: ASIAN WOMAN
dialogues.text: You can't be here -- court order --

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (screams) You won't let me see my fucking kids?

dialogues.speaker: ASIAN WOMAN
dialogues.text: I'm calling 911, Sandy -- now --

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: If I can't see them you won't see them -- She reaches for the phone. Before her hand touches it, he pulls a GUN and SHOOTS at her once -- blood sprays the pictures of the children -- she goes down.

dialogues.speaker: ON ERICA
dialogues.text: Watching it on the curved security mirror mounted on the ceiling. She is frozen in terror.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Fucking woman -- try seeing them now. He SHOOTS her AGAIN and AGAIN. Then reaches over and grabs handfuls of cash from the register.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: My money, too --

dialogues.speaker: ON ERICA
dialogues.text: As she watches in utter horror. She breaks out in beads of sweat as she crouches lower to stay out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: ON GUNMAN
dialogues.text: The gunman stuffs the money in his pocket, heads for the BACK DOOR. He's almost out, but he HEARS a CELL PHONE RINGING from the back of the store. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ON ERICA
dialogues.text: She pulls the PHONE from her pocket and fumbles to turn it OFF. Too late. In the surveillance mirror she sees the GUNMAN heading her way. She's trapped -- terrified.

dialogues.speaker: ON GUNMAN
dialogues.text: He rounds the corner -- and sees something, distorted by the display of bottles to his left -- The muzzle of a Kahr K-9. The last thing he ever sees is a FLASH OF FIRE from the barrel as Erica pulls the trigger, BLOWING the bottles apart.

dialogues.speaker: ON ERICA
dialogues.text: as she FIRES TWICE more, blindly, BOTTLES SHATTERING. She listens to the silence then. Peers 'round the shelf that divided them. Sees a spray of blood, hitting a tomato can. Below it, the gunman dying, blood spouting from a single shot to his jugular vein. And then, in an act more significant than she knows, she pulls it together: She lowers the cocked hammer on her semi-automatic and puts it back in her pocket. She surveys the STORE -- sees the SURVEILLANCE CAMERA pointed down at her. She looks at the woman's dead body behind the counter and realizes she is beyond help. She reaches in, ejects the tape from the machine behind. She looks at the blood on the sleeve of her coat, wipes some from her cheek, hurries out of the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica moves quickly down the street, not looking back, then quickly glances over her shoulder as she turns the corner.

Gentrification hasn't reached this far -- not yet. Erica, walking fast, almost maniacally, as if to get as far away as possible from what she has done. Blonde, thin, she walks, and gets looks from whoever is left on the streets, "what the fuck is she doing there?" But they leave her alone, not even sure why, they just know enough to keep going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercer sits on his own in a late-night bar. A woman comes through the entrance and towards him. JACKIE, a trial lawyer, well-dressed and pretty.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: You shouldn't work this late.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Had a client dinner.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Sea-Breeze, right? She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: You said this was business, Sean.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: It is. I need a favor from you. You heard about the Murrow thing?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Yes. His wife killed herself.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Women never shoot themselves in the face. In my experience.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Where do they shoot themselves? In your experience?

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: The heart. Their eyes meet. Jackie looks down. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: She was about to turn state's evidence. Three years I been trying to nail this asshole. Instead of blowing the lid on him, she blows her own lid off?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: You never let go, do you?

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: And you think it's your fault. It's killing you.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Maybe. She shifts uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: So what can I do?

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Her daughter might be able to tell me something, but he's applied for custody. With the lawyers he can afford, he'll get it, unless --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: He's the father?

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Stepfather.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: And you want her made a ward of court?

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: She knows he did it. She might be next. He reaches out to touch her hand.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: I thought maybe you could -- act on her behalf -- 36. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Sean, I'm your ex-wife. Conflict of interest and all that. And I don't do pro-bono.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: You did once.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I grew up. She withdraws her hand. She looks

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Look at yourself. The same old obsessive thing. The law, justice, the bad guy out there. Sometimes they get away with it. You have to learn to let go.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Do I?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: If you want a life. But I'm kind of glad you asked to meet.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's nice to see you.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Because I've something to tell you. at him.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I'm pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: I take that back. It's not nice to see you.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: You're fast. I miss that about you. He is devastated. But he covers it well.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: So. You got there, huh? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Remember that little blue thing? It went pink.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Blue and pink. I used to get them mixed up.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Well, pink is when you're pregnant. (softly) And now is when I want to have it. Mercer smiles, bleakly.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: He's happy about it, and so am I. I don't expect you to be over the moon, but I thought you should know. He can't take it anymore. He stands.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Jackie -- He kisses her, on the cheek. Gently. Saying goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: See? I didn't lose it. I didn't say I'd break his face. I didn't say I'd like to throw you through that plate-glass window.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: You never lose it --

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: I'm a cop. We investigate that shit. We don't do it. He goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercer enters, turns on the light. A lonely figure among the empty desks. An old tape machine there. He presses the button. We hear a woman's voice -- the voice of Murrow's dead wife. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MURROW'S WIFE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (on tape) I'd tell you more, but I'm afraid. I know the things he does, I know where the blood money comes from, but have you ever been afraid of your own house, your own bedroom, of the man you have to sleep beside? When I get my daughter out of there, I'll tell you things. When I make her safe, I'll tell you things. Until then, I'm afraid of my own shadow. He takes out her file, looks at the dead woman's photo. His ex-wife was right, it is killing him.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: (softly) I'm sorry. It is almost a relief when his CELL PHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Mercer -- (listens) Okay. I'm on my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica enters, locks the door behind her. She goes to a cabinet, takes out the first bottle she sees, pours herself a glass. She takes the gun and videotape out of her pocket, peels out of her coat. Throws the TAPE in a drawer. She sits on the sofa, hands hanging off her knees, a speck of blood riding her cheek --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica lets the shower pound her body. Thinner still than when we first saw her, more desperate, and somehow, at least in this light, more powerful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police cars, ambulances, and the coroner's van are parked on the street in front of the store, red lights bouncing off the glass. Mercer pulls up in his detective car.  53 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A police photographer photographs the dead body behind the counter. Several uniforms stand around. Mercer walks through the crowded interior, looking, trying to form a scene that makes sense. Mercer joins Vitale and kneels down beside the body.

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: (enthusiastic) Hey, good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Any I.D. yet?

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: Sandy Combs -- twenty-nine, rap sheet longer than my dick.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: So, in other words, no priors.

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: The victim is a thirty-year-old Vietnamese female -- Ida... Hands Mercer her I.D.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Combs. So what does that tell us?

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: They were married? See, I'm way ahead of you.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: One way to end it. He looks from the woman's body to the man's.

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: What's wrong with divorce?

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Everything. Divorce sucks. So, tell me --

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: He shot her in the neck, torso and face. Thirty-eight. Then somebody smoked him. Nine millimeter automatic. Don't ask me who. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mercer looks over at the cash strewn on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Why didn't they take the money?

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: Got scared? Vitale takes a plastic bag out of his coat pocket. It contains three shell casings.

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: They picked this up -- looks like there's a partial print on one but it's smudged.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Did you check the surveillance tape?

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: Machine's empty -- That bugs Mercer. He goes to the drawer under the machine -- finds a tape -- STICKS one in -- it PLAYS.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Machine's working -- where's the tape? Vitale shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Three casings. He was only hit once. What does that tell you?

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: Crappy shooter. Looking at the body. The entry wound in the neck.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Or. He'd never shot a gun before. Mercer studies the entry point, and angle of entry of the bullet -- steps back, looks at the dead man, draws an imaginary trajectory in his mind and walks over to where Erica was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica, hair wet from the shower, is sitting on the couch. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cigarette in one hand, gun in the other, fighting tears of anguish. But she faces, doesn't hide from, what she has done. SEES HERSELF IN THE MARKET -- PULLING THE TRIGGER. She gets up, OPENS a WINDOW for air -- feels the air on her skin, more afraid of what's in her, but a lot less afraid of what's outside --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercer enters to an EMPTY APARTMENT. He walks in, pours himself a drink, pulls open a drawer below the drinks cabinet. A picture there, of himself and Jackie. And a wedding ring.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It is astonishing... numbing to find that there is inside you a stranger...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica is sitting on the couch, a small tape machine in front of her, talking to it, as if she's the only person in the world.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: one who has your hands, your eyes, your legs... a sleepless, restless stranger... who keeps walking, keeps eating, keeps living...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercer, in bed, wide-awake in his quiet, empty apartment. He gets up -- starts getting dressed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The photo of him and Jackie is still by the drinks cabinet. He shoves it back in the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica is asleep on the couch. The dawn LIGHT streams through her window. Falls across her face, lighting it. But light isn't what she craves, she opens her eyes, turns in to find the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: HOLD ON HER FACE
dialogues.text: She can't escape, she is alive, and it is hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica, in front of her tape machine. Reading from scribbled notes.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: New York, like any metropolis, is an organism that changes, mutates, buildings sprout like chromosomes on the DNA of its streets -- She reaches for the pack of anti-depressants, then stops herself. She hits rewind on the tape machine, and as her words play back to her, goes to the bathroom and empties the pills down the toilet. Flushes it. Then, on impulse, throws her cigarette pack in the trash can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica sits across from Carol Olsen. Carol is looking at her with that very strong, very direct gaze of hers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I have two shows ready to go. I have almost six in various stages, most are ready or close to ready. And I have tons of ideas in my files. There's a lot more stuff I want to do. New. Better. (pushing) I know what I'm doing. You know that. I mean --

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Erica, you've been through so much. You need more time before you put yourself out there -- Erica feels it slipping away.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Don't make me beg.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I don't mean to. But we have a public. I'm not sure you're ready for it -- Carol's made her decision -- an awkward moment as she waits for Erica to accept it.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: You're saying I can't work because of what happened to me.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Im saying you need time to heal.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I need to keep living. And I don't want to disappear... Carol looks at her, that's the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she walks down the corridor. Some co-workers smile at her, some look away, some try to lock into her, to let her know they care -- Erica's expression doesn't change as she moves down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica is in front of a soundboard and a mic. She looks at her NOTES. She looks at the RED LIGHT. Takes a sip of water and looks back at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercer is driving -- RAP ON the RADIO, he SWITCHES STATIONS -- ALT ROCK, OLDIES -- CLASSICAL, NKW...

dialogues.speaker: ERICA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (on radio) This is Erica Bain and I walk the city...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through her HEADPHONES we HEAR the montage of city sounds she recorded earlier. Looks at the LIGHT again -- as she does, it turns

dialogues.speaker: YELLOW --
dialogues.text: She shifts her body. Takes another sip of water, as she does the light changes from yellow to GREEN. Time for her COMMENTARY, the end of her piece. She takes a breath and begins.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: New York, like any metropolis is an organism that -- And she stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol waiting --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound ENGINEER, his head wrapped in earphones.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 70 71 72 73 THE BRAVE ONE - Rev. 8/29/06 46.

dialogues.text: Silent -- dead air. Carol is angry. She knew it. She presses a button on the console in front of her.

dialogues.text: Anything else we can cut to? Music, pre-record, anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ENGINEER looks up at Erica, about to pull the plug --

dialogues.speaker: ENGINEER
dialogues.text: Shit --

dialogues.text: He turns it up -- nothing.

dialogues.text: Just her, the mic, and the empty, dark room. She begins again.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: New York, like any metropolis... And she stops again. Then, she looks down at her notes, moves them aside, leans into the mic. Speaks personally, straight from the heart.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: New York the safest big city in the world. It is horrible to fear the place you once loved. To see a (street) corner you knew so well and familiar steps and be unable to climb them. Her voice strong, intimate.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I never understood how people lived with fear. (people who lived with (in) fear) She pauses, considers the weight of the word.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Women who were afraid to walk home alone...

dialogues.text: A frown crosses Carol's face -- this is not what she was expecting.

dialogues.text: It never touched me. And then it did...

dialogues.text: A man cleaning skyscraper windows, high up, the city below him, with its millions of lives. A radio on the platform.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And when it touches you, you know it's been there all along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josai, cleaning the floor in an elegant apartment. A well-dressed woman in the b.g. turns UP the RADIO dial. Erica's voice fills the room. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERICA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Waiting, behind the surfaces of all the things you loved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica walks past the graffiti-scrawled wall of a cemetery. She walks through the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: your skin crawls, your heart aches, you look at the person that was once you, walking down that street...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica in front of David's grave -- coat, backpack --

dialogues.speaker: ERICA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: and wonder will she ever be you again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FULL MOON scatters light across the dark, empty cemetery. Erica is still there, waiting to feel something, but she feels nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: talk to me...

dialogues.text: Erica on her way home from the cemetery; Erica rides the near-empty car, the ride soothing her. Down the car, two GUYS in hoodies are sitting opposite a STUDENT, listening to his IPOD, giving him grief.

dialogues.text: You little shit -- The Father wrestles his head free, brings his hand up. But the Guy has a knife out now, to his nose.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Good at it, too -- Finally the train comes to a STOP. The man takes the opportunity to grab his boy's hand and head for the doors. The Student follows, looking back to see Erica, sitting calmly at the back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Tell your mother I said, 'What's up.'

dialogues.text: They CLOSE, train starts.

dialogues.text: I got me an iPOD. And the guys notice, at the back, the only one left.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Oh shit. You're kidding, right?

dialogues.speaker: ON ERICA
dialogues.text: sitting at the far end of the car.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Na na na, (Yo, yo, yo) I got this. He walks toward her, the other Guy follows.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Bitch, is you crazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he moves VERY CLOSE to her, flicks her earbuds out of her ears with his knife.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: (soft) You gonna give me some Radiohead too? You ever been fucked by a knife? Suddenly -- he is thrown back, a MIST OF BLOOD, as the BULLET blows through his back. The other one lunges toward her, she FIRES again, he spins around and staggers toward the other end of the car. Wounded, he falls back against the doors. His head slides to one side as he dies, blood streaking the doors. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 718 THE BRAVE ONE - Rev. 8/29/06 50A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The car slows, approaches the next station. Erica slides the pistol back in her recorder bag as the doors open. The man's torso slides onto the platform with the doors, half in, half out of the subway car. She walks out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Behind her, the subway doors slide closed. The dead man's body blocks them, stopping the train.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: why don't my hands shake...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica, walking rapidly up the stairs, into a long, neon- lit corridor. The CAMERA SWIRLS AROUND her, as she tries to quell her panic, then heads for the nearest exit.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: how can I watch myself push through that turnstile and walk away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica emerges and walks into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercer is at his desk, on his computer, working. Vitale walks through, his CELL PHONE in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: They got two confirmed shot, on a subway from Brooklyn, Church Street, lower Manhattan. Everyone arguing whose jurisdiction it is -- Mercer thinks for a moment, then stands.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Makes it ours? He makes for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica, still walking. The sounds of POLICE SIRENS WAILING. She stops. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: LIT BY THE FLASHING POLICE LIGHTS: A strange sense of blankness in her face. Mixed with the WAILING OF SIRENS is the THUMP OF MUSIC from a nearby bar. She abruptly turns, and walks into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUD MUSIC. A brash, dating crowd. Erica pushes through a sea of men's faces and walks down circular stairs towards the restroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica pushes through the door and dry-retches into the sink. Her face is now covered in beads of sweat. She runs the taps and bathes her face in water. Breathes deeply, looks up at the stranger in the mirror. Herself.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Hey, you... ON her face in the mirror. Unnaturally calm, again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRIGHT POLICE ARC LIGHTS blast the tunnel. Police are everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two bodies are right where they died. There is a whole raft of cops, fingerprint specialists, photographers, coroner, etc. Mercer and Vitale arrive at the scene.

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: He holds up a shell casing on the tip of a pencil as Vitale walks over.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: An automatic. Nine millimeter. Like the other night. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Check it against Brass-Catcher, see if it matches. He gives Vitale the casing, walks over to one of the bodies, crouches down, looks at the tear the bullet made in the guy's T-shirt, checks the angle and level of entry. Looks at the IPOD next to the GUY, the ALBUM COVER still on the screen -- RADIOHEAD, looks at the dead guy's clothes -- not a fit -- he turns the IPOD over, sees the SERIAL NUMBER, bags it. Vitale comes over.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Neither one robbed. Both have cash in their pockets. The CORONER and an assistant start to bag the body of the man who died sitting up.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Hey, what're you doing?

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: (attitude) Takin' him to the morgue.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: I'll tell you when you can take him.

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: My shift is ending, as it is I'll be lucky if I have time for both bodies. So, how about you just let me do my job?

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: (impatient) How about you don't do anything until I'm done?

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: How about, fuck you, asshole? He starts to bag the body; Mercer's so shocked it takes him a second to respond. Just as he starts for the guy, Vitale puts an arm out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: Not worth it, buddy. (off the Coroner) He's a roach. He'll outlast you and everybody else. Mercer calms himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica emerges, tense, nervous, from the bar. More lights flash past her face, as TV trucks and news crews arrive. She looks at the subway entrance, sees the gathering crowd around it. She is pinioned for a moment, drawn to the scene, yet repulsed by it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercer walks over to the knife on the ground, the trail of blood across the floor.

dialogues.text: They both have priors?

dialogues.text: A busload of them.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: That guy at Sandy's had priors, and wasn't robbed.

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: That was domestic --

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Yeah -- I don't know, there's something. Walks around, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: None of the three were robbed -- all three had priors -- He walks over and sits where Erica sat.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Small guy. Sitting here. Two punks come at him with a knife -- shoots the first one without even getting out of his seat -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe some asshole with a gun decided it's time to take matters into his own hand, time for a little street justice. Kind of guy you wouldn't even notice.

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: Damn -- if that's true --

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: He's getting better. Every bullet hit home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gathering crowd, local TV trucks arriving. Yellow tape around the subway entrance. Police keeping the crowds out... And Erica, finally, turns and walks back towards the scene. If anything or anyone is going to stop her, it will be there. Everything about her is different -- her walk, the hunch of her shoulders, she's thin, pale -- both exposed and protected, damaged and tough, a ghost and a new being all wrapped up in one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercer follows Erica's path up the steps, onto the nearest platform. He looks left and right. Two exits. He heads for the nearest one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercer emerging from the subway entrance. There's still a CROWD, and some media. A couple of REPORTERS try to ask him questions, he waves them off. As he turns away, he sees a FACE he thinks he recognizes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They catch eyes for just a moment -- but it's enough to make Erica turn, walk away.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER, (0O.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey. Hang on. She stops. Panicked, suddenly. Tries to quell it, her face turned away from him. She finally succeeds, and turns to face him.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Don't I know you -- * Her eyes, meeting his. Will this be the moment that makes her stop?

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Don't think we've ever met. On his face. Trying to place her. And she has to fill in the silence.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: No, wait. I know you. What's * your name? *

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Erica Bain. I -- ah -- do a radio show. He places her now. The hospital. *

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? * She is stuck. But she covers well. *

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: If you'd consider -- being on the * show -- *

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: We're not really ready to talk to... the media...

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I'm not that kind of media. My * audience is... (gestures with her fingers) tiny...

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Yeah? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I try to give a different slant... stories... of the city. But look, if you're not into it --

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: My life is not that interesting.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: The work you do is.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: No thanks. She nods, turns away, walks through the crowd, and out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercer at his desk. He is checking on his computer, and we SEE the name ERICA BAIN. Stuff on her case comes up. Vitale enters, reading the New York Post. He pours himself coffee.

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: Any more shitheads die while we were sleeping?

dialogues.text: Not that I know of.

dialogues.text: Crappy coffee -- Mercer nods. There is a pile of messages on his desk, most from REPORTERS. Vitale tosses the Post on the desk, headline blaring: VIGILANTE???

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: (off newspaper) How the hell did that get out already?

dialogues.text: Who knows? The coroner hates you, all the technicians, and fucking people, who knows? Mercer shakes his head. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: (then) You ever listen to NKW?

dialogues.text: Remember that girl and her boyfriend who got jacked in Central Park a couple months ago?

dialogues.text: Remember that Bernie Goetz thing -- the guys said reporters were calling in the middle of the night. Reporters love this shit.

dialogues.text: Check the registration on this. See if you can trace it to the owner.

dialogues.text: Erica is walking back in from the kitchen area, waiting for her.

dialogues.text: You've been avoiding me.

dialogues.text: No I haven't.

dialogues.text: Look, I tried to do my regular show -- but it just wasn't in me.

dialogues.text: I never imagined a radio show could double as a psychiatrist's couch. But... Carol hands Erica a stack of emails -- Erica doesn't take them, Carol puts them on her desk --

dialogues.text: Erica is leaving the building. A blue SEDAN is parked at the curb. As Erica passes, Mercer jumps out, walks up to her. She looks at him, quickly glances down at his gun, his handcuffs. Looks around, instinctively wanting to run -- He puts on his jacket, covering the gun.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: You again.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Yeah. Me. Remember last night? She stops dead. Almost waiting for him to cuff her.

dialogues.text: What about last night?

dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) Well, I knew who you were, I mean, I recognized you. And I didn't say anything and I should have. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: I saw you in the hospital -- after what happened to you and your friend --

dialogues.text: I stopped by your room because I recognized your name -- my wife used to listen to your show -- and that's why I stopped you at the subway, and I wanted you to know that.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.text: It was upsetting. You were -- gone. It's kind of strange to see someone that... can't see you. And now you're back.

dialogues.text: Well. Not everyone makes it back.

dialogues.text: (quietly) I know that. He reads her upset. Deals with it well.

dialogues.text: Yes. I know you know that. I checked into your case.

dialogues.text: Two of the best detectives in this city are on it. We'll find them. We always do. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Are you interviewing me?

dialogues.text: Eh... She is stuck now. But some part of her is intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Trying... He smiles. He assumes he can't get out of it.

dialogues.text: How long will it take?

dialogues.text: The strange emptiness of a cafe in mid-morning. A large screen TV is on in the B.G. with the SOUND OFF. Mercer and Erica sit at a table, across from each other.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Have you ever done an interview before?

dialogues.text: On air?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Actually that's not a bad idea --

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I could probably manage a full- blown breakdown. Just give me some notice --

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You don't get it, do you? Your psychotherapy on air, your FM confessional or whatever the fuck you want to call it has gotten you more exposure than you've ever had. 83. 110 111 Carol (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I could do beauty tips for assault victims. One on ones with serial killers. Her ice cold fury stops Carol in her tracks.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You're being facetious.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: No, Carol, I am fucked up. I'm one of the walking wounded. So maybe you were right. It wasn't time. I should never have come back -- And she walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same police station Erica first called. She enters, looks at the police business filling the lobby area. Walks in deliberately, up to the cop on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I want to talk about... a homicide case.

dialogues.speaker: DESK COP
dialogues.text: Name?

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Erica Bain. He hits a few buttons on his computer.

dialogues.speaker: DESK COP
dialogues.text: She was the victim?

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: No. She wasn't the victim. She was the... she is the... And for a moment we think she might be about to turn herself in.

dialogues.speaker: DESK COP
dialogues.text: No Erica Bain under homicide, Ma'am. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: No? Well. Maybe there should be --

dialogues.speaker: DESK COP
dialogues.text: Pardon me? He looks up, puzzled, but she is already heading for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica by the Strangers Gate entrance. The steps seem to mock her.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Because I could not stop for Death. He kindly stopped for me. She can't go up there. She turns away, walks quickly on.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The carriage held but just ourselves. And immortality.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE ROAD
dialogues.text: Beyond the stream of traffic, we see Nicole, trying to get her attention.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Erica --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica, unaware of her, lost among the cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica is sitting inside the glass and steel dome of the ground floor of a parking lot, which looks out on the river. Next to her is a copy of the New York Post, in the box a picture of Murrow, the stepfather, and his daughter. She hits a button on her mobile and listens to the RINGING TONE.  86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercer's CELL PHONE is ECHOING in the near-empty apartment. He picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hello. Recognizes her voice right away.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: It's Erica --

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: I know. Is everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I just wanted to talk -- and for some reason you seem to make the most sense.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Okay. It's quiet -- connection in their silence.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: What? She shakes her head, as if he can see her.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: What do you do when you can't sleep?

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Isn't that hard? Can you stop thinking about stuff?

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: No. I'm used to it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Erica looks up, out at the dark river walkway, the looming rusted structure of a Bridge above it. A man is walking along the river walk, towards the parking lot. We recognize him. MURROW, the stepfather.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Erica -- Doesn't say anything, just listens to his voice.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: What's going on? (quiet) Talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Did you sleep better when your wife was next to you? Silence. He shakes his head --

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I did. I could never feel my body unless he was wrapped around me.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: My wife used to flip. I'd call her the mackerel. But waking beside someone like that is not... the worst... Below, Murrow walks towards the elevator. He presses the button, and the elevator responds with a loud "PING" sound. INT. MERCER'S APARTMENT - SAME TIME Al19 Mercer hears the "PING" sound.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: (half-kidding) You want me to stay on the phone until you fall asleep? She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: You've been good to me. Good night. She closes the cell phone. She walks to the elevator, on her level. Presses the button. It PINGS again. And as it ascends towards her, it PINGS at each floor. Then the doors open. And there he is. She enters, without giving him a glance.  119 120 88.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murrow stares at the elevator dial, which makes the same PINGING sound as it hits every floor. He glances briefly at Erica. Then his CELL PHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: Yeah -- how late? Look, you told me it would be there, so it better be there. He closes his cell phone. Erica glances down at his feet. HIS SHOES -- immaculately polished, hand tailored. The elevator doors open, at the top floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rusting bridge, gleaming over the water, old factories across the way. A few cars still parked on the open rooftop. Murrow walks out of the elevator. After a beat, Erica follows. As Murrow reaches his car door, she speaks, from behind him.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Why do you think you can hurt people?

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: What? He turns.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Can you do damage and just walk away? Do you know what you leave behind? She looks quite crazy from Murrow's point of view. He turns away.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Hey -- I'm asking you --

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: (irritated) Do I know you?

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Do you think about it? (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERICA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Does it keep you awake at night -- does it haunt you?

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: It haunts me --

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: You one of those press, paparazzo freaks? She has her hand beneath her jacket, about to take out her gun. He takes a crowbar from the car and suddenly turns on her.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: You got a camera there, huh? Yeah, well I have something for you. He lunges at her with the crowbar. Erica brings her hand up to protect her face. The crowbar slices through her jacket, opening her skin. She staggers backwards.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: Take my fucking picture? Come to my place, take my picture? He brings the crowbar down towards her again. She twists her body, to avoid it and finds herself face-to-face with him. She suddenly slams her forehead into the bridge of his nose. He staggers back, dropping the crowbar, his nose exploding with blood.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: What the fuck -- are you a cop? Erica bends down to pick up the crowbar.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: You wish...

dialogues.speaker: ON HIS FACE
dialogues.text: As she swings down the crowbar --  121 90.

dialogues.text: Mercer, staring stunned at something on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Jesus H Christ --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The body of Murrow, fallen from the car park above. His body is wrecked, a bloody crowbar part of the wreckage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uniforms around. Vitale with them.

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: Fell from up there. Mercer follows his gaze, to the top of the apartment lot.

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: Cause of death, maybe the fall, maybe the crowbar stuck in his skull. I'd say fifty-fifty, * either one.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Shit. Off the body, the blood, the guy's head smashed in.

dialogues.text: I mean, how many people wanted this prick dead? Besides me?

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: So someone did us a favor, huh? * Maybe we should put them on the * payroll... *

dialogues.text: You mean someone out there, thinks * he's doing our job for us? * Sending us a message? Here's how * it's done? * (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: You think maybe he's right?

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: No. You dont either. The press circus is arriving, in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: You deal with them. I wanna check the roof. Mercer stands. He has a terrible feeling about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercer, by the elevator. He hits the button, to take him upstairs. And the button sounds -- "PING." He registers it. He has heard that somewhere before.

dialogues.speaker: ON HIS FACE
dialogues.text: As the elevator makes the SOUND ONCE MORE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica outside her door, trying to work the keys with her good arm. As she finally gets the door open, Josai comes down from upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: JOSAI
dialogues.text: Erica? Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Erica collapses on the floor. As Josai pushes through from outside, Erica tries to stop the door with her foot.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Get out --

dialogues.speaker: JOSAI
dialogues.text: My god -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She sees Erica on the ground, her shirt covered in blood. Erica screams.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Get away --

dialogues.speaker: JOSAI
dialogues.text: No. I won't get away. She tries to lift Erica off the floor.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Don't touch me -- I'm sick -- Erica's too weak to resist her. As Josai drags her to the table, the gun falls on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: JOSAI
dialogues.text: I can see that -- And finally Erica cracks. Shudders of weeping go through her, as Josai holds her, trying to calm her.

dialogues.speaker: JOSAI
dialogues.text: Hush now. Hush. As the shuddering subsides --

dialogues.speaker: JOSAI
dialogues.text: We have to get you to a hospital.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JOSAI
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Because I can't.

dialogues.speaker: JOSAI
dialogues.text: What kind of trouble are you in?

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: You don't want to know. Josai lets this sit.

dialogues.speaker: JOSAI
dialogues.text: Okay then. Take your coat off -- Erica allows Josai to remove her coat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOSAI
dialogues.text: And your shirt. Josai looks at her bloodied arm.

dialogues.speaker: JOSAI
dialogues.text: Sit still a minute. She goes to the bathroom, brings back alcohol, bandages, tape. Erica winces as Josai applies alcohol to the wound.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: (off Josai's steady hand) Were you a nurse?

dialogues.speaker: JOSAI
dialogues.text: When I had to be. She threads the needle, plunges it through Erica's skin, quickly, efficiently. Erica slumps into a chair from the pain. Josai cuts the thread with her teeth.

dialogues.speaker: JOSAI
dialogues.text: This is going to leave a scar.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I killed a man tonight.

dialogues.speaker: JOSAI
dialogues.text: Because he did this to you?

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: No. I would have killed him anyway. Josai looks at the gun on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: JOSAI
dialogues.text: Back home -- they gave young boys guns, made them kill their parents. Just to show us. Anyone can cross that line. Anyone can be a killer. Anyone can have those dead eyes. And each death leaves a hole, waiting to be filled.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: How -- how do you fill it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOSAI
dialogues.text: That depends on you. She looks back down at the gun, lying on the floor, like a question mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercer, trailed by Vitale, walks through.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Did the coroner get his liver temperature?

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: Dead about two hours when we got there.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: That puts it at --

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: 2 A.M. Give or take --

dialogues.speaker: ON MERCER
dialogues.text: It is all adding up to something he doesn't want to contemplate.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: I want everyone from the market killing, the subway brought in again.

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: We've done all that.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: We got to do it again. We need to think outside the box here.

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: Nailed him with that crowbar, hefted him over that rail, we're not talking about a little guy anymore --

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Maybe not. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He keeps his suspicions to himself.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: What about that IPOD? You said you traced it to a kid?

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: His father's a lawyer, asked for a subpoena. I'm onto it.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Whatever you have to do, just get him in here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercer in his car. He scrolls down the numbers in his cell phone to find Erica's.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: (when she answers) Just wanted to know how you slept.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Pretty well.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Look -- you want to see what I do? Meet me outside Woodhull Hospital. You'll get some idea -- EXT. UNIVERSITY SQUARE - DAY Al27 Ethan, the IPOD student from the subway train, smokes a joint with some friends. Vitale, watching him from his car. He gets out, closes the door, walks towards the bench on which they are sitting. Ethan, seeing him coming, quenches the joint. Flicks it away.

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: Ethan Grant -- He displays his badge. He eyeballs the other kids, and they scatter.

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: We need to talk some more -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I told you, my dad said not to get involved -- Vitale bends down, takes the quenched joint from the grass.

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: Does your dad know how much dope you smoke? That's more than a misdemeanor these days --

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I saw nothing --

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: I think you did. He sniffs the joint.

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: You sell this shit?

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: I believe you. Maybe a judge won't. He grabs him by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: VITALE
dialogues.text: Come on --

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Nice jacket. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Erica and Mercer head down a hallway toward a UNIFORMED COP who sits in a chair in front of a room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chloe there, her leg in a cast. She's medicated, an IV hangs from a stand next to the bed. Mercer stands next to the bed, Erica just behind him. Chloe opens her eyes. It takes only a second for her glazed eyes to lock onto Erica.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: How you doing today?

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Alright... She looks at Erica. Back at Mercer.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: So maybe you can talk now? Tell me what you remember. A slight smile plays around her lips.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: You gonna tell us what you saw that night? Chloe raises her finger and points at Erica. It's like being in the sights of a gun. Mercer looks from Chloe to Erica.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Are you trying to say something?

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: That's -- On her hand, still pointing.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: That's a pretty necklace. Erica takes it from her neck and places it in her hand. Wraps her own hand around Chloe's. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: You should tell him, you know. Whatever you saw. Chloe looks from Erica to Mercer.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: I saw one of those... guardian angels. Like in the bible.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: You did, huh?

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Yeah. They save you... Bring you to a better place... She turns away to the wall, shutting them both off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercer walking back with Erica, glancing at her, casual and intense.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Did that upset you?

dialogues.text: Of course. She walks in silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I wasn't much help there, was I?

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Depends on what you mean by help. She stops. Is this a direct accusation? Then he covers it.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: You... gave her your necklace.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: It meant a lot to me. Erica gives a tense smile, walks on.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Erica? She turns. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Why did you call me last night? *

dialogues.text: So you were in bed, right? *

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: That's where I sleep. * Mercer watches her walk away -- her body, the way she moves, tries to imagine her, this woman he can't get out of his head, killing someone...

dialogues.text: Now, tell us again, why didn't you come in before?

dialogues.text: Watch it.

dialogues.text: (shaking his head) You were glad?

This is a phenomenon that happens quite often -- the mind gets so saturated with popular images it's often difficult, especially for people under twenty, to recall something unique. dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.text: Sit down. Number two, approach the mirror. A SECOND SUSPECT walks forward, faces the mirror. Erica looks, shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.text: Sit down. Number three, approach the mirror. The THIRD SUSPECT walks forward, stands in front of the mirror. Erica stares at him -- he stares back as if he can see her. A slight smile plays at REED'S lips. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: I'm off, let me buy you some lunch.

dialogues.text: (watching her reaction) Sorry you had to go through that -- we really thought we had him. She says nothing. She is looking at her ring.

dialogues.text: I can hardly remember his hands.

dialogues.text: That guy we saw on TV, at the coffee shop, I've been trying to put him away for months. Someone else must have had something against him. We're not talking about nine millimeter here. It got personal.

dialogues.text: I read about it.

dialogues.text: We got some more information on that subway shooting. Turns out there was a woman in the car that night. We've been looking for a guy with a gun, instead it's a woman with a grudge --

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I'm sure there's a lot of us out there. She has made a direct admission. He registers this. It is so thick between them now, every word is weighted. Cop and suspect, man, woman, lover.

dialogues.text: I used to give myself a test, Erica. When I was a rookie. If someone I knew committed a crime, would I put them away.

dialogues.text: What kind of someone?

dialogues.text: Someone close to me. Like the best friend I ever could have had. He means her. And she knows it.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: I always hoped I would have had the courage, the dedication to say yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: And... do you?

dialogues.text: I do. And it's important that you know that.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I know that. I admire that about you. He looks directly at her.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Just one more piece of evidence, and she's going down.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: And I'm sure you'll find it. You're a good detective. You miss nothing. This is almost like a goodbye between them.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I have to go. I'll get it.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: It's mine -- He stops her hand, as she reaches for the bill.

dialogues.text: What do you think David would think of...

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Or what? Mercer looks directly at her.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Of you. Now.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I don't know. The dead don't talk. At least not to me. Erica removes her hand from his -- leans down, and kisses him, on the cheek, gently, apologetically. (CONTINUED)

She comes to the recessed entrance of number 90. The number above the door seems to taunt her. She walks toward it. She lights her cigarette lighter. The flame of the lighter illuminates the button panel. About a hundred metal bell-pushes, the names below them scratched and obscured. As she's about to push them at random, the door suddenly opens. dialogues.text: On the ground -- Lee drops, like a stone. Erica, on the ground, grabbing for her gun.
